title: Fast epsilon-free Inference of Simulation Models with Bayesian Conditional Density Estimation
other: [Code](https://github.com/gpapamak/epsilon_free_inference)

title: Flexible statistical inference for mechanistic models of neural dynamics
other: [Code](https://github.com/mackelab/delfi)

title: Automatic posterior transformation for likelihood-free inference
other: [Code](https://github.com/mackelab/delfi)

title: Likelihood-free inference with emulator networks
Sequential Neural Likelihood: Fast Likelihood-free Inference with Autoregressive Flows
other: [Code](https://github.com/gpapamak/snl)

title: BayesFlow: Learning complex stochastic models with invertible neural networks
other: [Code](https://github.com/stefanradev93/cINN)

title: Likelihood-free MCMC with Amortized Approximate Ratio Estimators
other: [Code](https://github.com/montefiore-ai/hypothesis)

title: Score Matched Neural Exponential Families for Likelihood-Free Inference
other: [Code](https://github.com/LoryPack/SM-ExpFam-LFI)

title: Sequential Neural Posterior and Likelihood Approximation
other: [Code](https://github.com/SamuelWiqvist/snpla)
They use normalizing flows for both the posterior and the likelihood.
They also optionally use an additional NN for learning summary statistics at the same time.

title: MINIMALIST: Mutual INformatIon Maximization for Amortized Likelihood Inference from Sampled Trajectories
other: [Code](https://github.com/statbiophys/MINIMALIST)

title: Arbitrary Marginal Neural Ratio Estimation for Simulation-based Inference
other: Extension of Hermans et al. 2019 (above) which allows to explicitly obtain every possible marginal
Thanks to this you can plot marginals with no need of posterior sampling
[Code](https://github.com/francois-rozet/amnre)

title: Variational Likelihood-Free Gradient Descent
other: Considers a set of particles which will be a posterior approximation
The particles are fitted to the posterior by alternating between NN training and Stein Variaional Gradient Descent steps

title: GATSBI: Generative Adversarial Training for Simulation-Based Inference
other: Uses Generative Adversarial Networks to represent the posterior.
[Code](https://github.com/mackelab/gatsbi)

title: Robust and integrative Bayesian neural networks for likelihood-free parameter inference
other: They bin the parameter values and use a classifier to predict the exact parameter value from data
The classifier is a BNN and is trained on a set of parameter-data pairs
When a new observation comes, the posterior is estimated by MCMC on the posterior weights and combining the set of predictions of the classifier into a (discretized) posterior distribution.

title: Variational methods for simulation-based inference
other: [Code](https://github.com/mackelab/snvi_repo)
They consider the standard likelihood or likelihood-ratio approaches and replace MCMC with a variational inference done via normalizing flows
In this way you get benefits of targeting likelihood with no need of MCMC
Related to Wiqvist et al. (2021) above.

title: Conditional Simulation Using Diffusion Schrödinger Bridges
other: They use denoising diffusion models on an extended state space which allows for Likelihood-Free Bayesian Inference

title: Detecting Model Misspecification in Amortized Bayesian Inference with Neural Networks
other: [Code](https://github.com/marvinschmitt/ModelMisspecificationBF)
They add probabilistic structure to learned summary statistics to detect model misspecification with MMD, e.g. for APT/SNPE-C (Greenberg et al., 2019) or BayesFlow (Radev et al., 2020).

title: Likelihood approximation networks (LANs) for fast inference of simulation models in cognitive neuroscience
other: [Code](https://github.com/lnccbrown/lans)
They use NNs to directly approximate likelihood estimates obtained by KDE or binned empirical estimates from repeated model simulations.

title: On Contrastive Learning for Likelihood-free Inference
other: [Code](https://github.com/conormdurkan/lfi)
They unify the ratio estimation approach by Hermans et al. (2019) with the sequential neural posterior formulation of Greenberg et al. (2019).

title: The frontier of simulation-based inference
other: They discuss recent advaces in LFI, including NN-based methods.

title: Benchmarking Simulation-Based Inference
other: [Code](https://github.com/sbi-benchmark/sbibm)
Benchmark repository for LFI methods.
They test the performance of LFI methods (including NN-based ones) on a variety of models and data sets.
Interactive results at [this webpage](https://sbi-benchmark.github.io/)

title: SBI -- A toolkit for simulation-based inference
other: [Code](https://github.com/mackelab/sbi)
A Python toolbox for simulation-based inference methods based on NNs.
Documentation at [this webpage](https://www.mackelab.org/sbi/)

title: Distortion estimates for approximate Bayesian inference
other: They use normalizing flows to build distortion maps which acts on univariate marginals of the approximate posterior to move them closer to the exact posterior, without evaluation of the latter, for a specific observation.
Can be applied to any posterior approximation, provided simulations from the model are doable.

title: Group equivariant neural posterior estimation
other: Extension of the Neural Posterior Estimation approach with normalizing flows to incorporate equivariant transformations.
The methods works without changing the NN architecture, instead transforming the data via another transformation before feeding it into the NN. The transformation is also parametrized by a NN.

It defines a joint posterior on parameters and transformation and then obtain posterior samples via Gibbs sampling on the two conditionals (each conditional sampling steps do not require MCMC, as normalizing flows are used for the conditional on parameters and blurring via a kernel is used for the transformation conditional).

title: Likelihood-Free Inference with Generative Neural Networks via Scoring Rule Minimization
other: [Code](https://github.com/LoryPack/LFI_gen_networks_Scoring_Rules)
Same setup as Ramesh et al., but training the generative network via scoring rule minimization rather than adversarial training.

title: HNPE: Leveraging Global Parameters for Neural Posterior Estimation
other: [Code](https://github.com/plcrodrigues/HNPE)
They extend LFI methods using normalizing flows for Bayesian hierarchical models.

title: Amortized Bayesian model comparison with evidential deep learning
other: [Code](https://github.com/stefanradev93/BayesFlow)
Way to perform model selection using a NN to estimate the model evidence
Amortized over the different models, so that they do not need to be fit to the data independently

title: Analyzing Inverse Problems with Invertible Neural Networks
other: Different way to train a normalizing flow for amortized posterior inference with respect to Radev et al. 2021.

title: Hierarchical Implicit Models and Likelihood-Free Variational Inference
other: Trains a generative network for inferring the posterior in hierarchical models.
For non-hierarchical models, the approach is very similar to GATSBI (Ramesh et al., 2021)

title: Efficient Amortised Bayesian Inference for Hierarchical and Nonlinear Dynamical Systems
other: [Code](https://github.com/Microsoft/vi-hds)
Use variational inference to train autoencoders for posterior inference.

title: Adversarial Bayesian Simulation
other: Uses Generative Adversarial Networks to represent the posterior.
Similar setup to Ramesh et al. 2022, but uses Wasserstein GANs instead of vanilla GANs and provides more theoretical insights.

title: Towards Reliable Simulation-Based Inference with Balanced Neural Ratio Estimation
other: [Code](https://github.com/montefiore-ai/balanced-nre)

Builds on the likelihood-ratio approach by Hermans et al. 2019 introducing an additional loss term which lead to conservative (instead of overconfident) posterior estimates with small amount of data hence avoiding false conclusions. The learned target converges to the exact posterior as the data size increases.

title: Investigating the Impact of Model Misspecification in Neural Simulation-based Inference
other: They empirically test the performance of neural likelihood-free inference methods with misspecified models, finding that performance is not robust
They investigate mitigation strategies such as ensemble posteriors and sharpness-aware minimization

title: Score Modeling for Simulation-based Inference
other: They use diffusion score models to approximate the posterior distribution
The network is trained on pairs of parameter and simulations, but it allows to sample from the posterior for an arbitrary number of simulations

title: Robust Neural Posterior Estimation and Statistical Model Criticism
other: They show Neural Posterior Estimation (NPE) performs poorly under model misspecification.
As a remedy, they develop a framework incluyding a model criticism and a robust inference components, by explicitly modelling the discrepancy between simulations and observations.
Their framework requires an MCMC.
[Code](https://github.com/danielward27/rnpe)

title: New Machine Learning Techniques for Simulation-Based Inference: InferoStatic Nets, Kernel Score Estimation, and Kernel Likelihood Ratio Estimation
other: They introduce three different strategies, based on kernels and a scalar function called the inferostatic potential.

title: Truncated proposals for scalable and hassle-free simulation-based inference
other: Performs sequential inference with truncated proposals, sidestepping the optimisation issues of alternative approaches.
[Code](https://github.com/tsnpeNeurips)

title: Fast Estimation of Bayesian State Space Models Using Amortized Simulation-Based Inference
other: Concentrates on the setting of Bayesian state-space models, by learning some marginals of the posterior directly
They use a normal approximation and learn the mean and standard deviation.

title: Sequential Neural Score Estimation: Likelihood-Free Inference with Conditional Score Based Diffusion Models
other: They introduce sequential algorithms to learn both the likelihood and the posterior using score-based networks.

title: Maximum Likelihood Learning of Energy-Based Models for Simulation-Based Inference
other: They exploit energy-based models to learn likelihood, in both an amortized and sequential framework
Their approach is similar to Pacchiardi and Dutta 2022, but they rely on an advanced Maximum Likelihood approach to tune the energy-based model.

They are also able to exploit standard MCMC for sampling from the amortized version (in contrast to MCMC for doubly-intractable targets needed by Pacchiard and Dutta, 2022, and by the sequential approach).
[Code](https://github.com/pierreglaser/unle)

title: Contrastive Neural Ratio Estimation
other: Generalization of Likelihood-free MCMC with Amortized Approximate Ratio Estimators and On Contrastive Learning for Likelihood-free Inference.
Multi-class ratio estimation but has returns exact likelihood-to-evidence ratio at optimum
[Code](https://github.com/bkmi/cnre)

title: Truncated Marginal Neural Ratio Estimation
other: Introduced a truncation scheme which can be tested for calibration to the prior, despite being sequential. Other sequential methods cannot be tested for calibration.
Introduced a technique of estimating necessary partially marginalized posterior distributions to increase simulation efficiency.
[Code](https://github.com/bkmi/tmnre)
Also see [general implementation](https://github.com/undark-lab/swyft)

title: Simulation-efficient marginal posterior estimation with swyft: stop wasting your precious time
other: Explored truncation and estimating marginals as an options to increase simulation-effiency
Expanded upon in Truncated Marginal Neural Ratio Estimation
This version of swyft has the code [code](https://github.com/undark-lab/swyft/releases/tag/v0.1.2)

title: swyft: Truncated Marginal Neural Ratio Estimation in Python
other: Created a flexible and general purpose simulation-based inference package which uses Truncated Marginal Neural Ratio Estimation.
[Toolbox](https://github.com/undark-lab/swyft/)

title: Error-Guided Likelihood-Free MCMC
other: Enables parameter inference for observations that are a given distance away from the true observation
Use distance of 0 for vanilla inference
Handy in applications with high-dimensional observations
